question_details.query: What actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: Closing roads during seasonal amphibian migrations protected large numbers of amphibians from death at closure sites, including where closures were combined with assisted crossings and barrier fences [842]. Installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings reduced amphibian road deaths in six of seven studies (in one case only when barrier fencing was also installed), with many studies reporting amphibians used the structures; use and effectiveness were influenced by design factors such as diameter, length, lighting, substrate, water presence, entrance location and tunnel climate, and some designs (e.g., one-way vertical chutes) caused high mortality, with one study still reporting thousands killed [884]. Using humans to assist migrating amphibians moved large numbers across roads, but studies reported 64–70% population declines over 6–10 years and over 500 toads still killed at 7% of sites [784]. Installing barrier fencing along roads, especially with culverts, decreased road deaths in seven of eight studies; at least 0.6 m height was required to prevent some frog species climbing over, though some species still climbed fences [756]. Modifying gully pots and kerbs by moving gully pots 10 cm from the kerb reduced great crested newts falling in by 80% [782].
summary_statements: Closing roads during seasonal amphibian migrations protected large numbers of amphibians from death at closure sites.
The protection of amphibians via road closures was also observed when closures were combined with assisted crossings and barrier fences.
Installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings reduced amphibian road deaths.
The effectiveness of culverts or tunnels in reducing amphibian road deaths was in one case dependent on barrier fencing also being installed.
Many studies reported that amphibians used culverts or tunnels installed as road crossings.
The use and effectiveness of road crossing structures were influenced by design factors including diameter, length, lighting, substrate, water presence, entrance location, and tunnel climate.
Some road crossing designs, such as one-way vertical chutes, caused high amphibian mortality.
Using humans to assist migrating amphibians moved large numbers of the animals across roads.
Despite human assistance for road crossings, amphibian populations experienced declines of 64–70% over 6–10 years.
Even with human assistance, over 500 toads were still killed at 7% of sites.
Installing barrier fencing along roads decreased amphibian road deaths.
The effectiveness of barrier fencing was increased when combined with culverts.
A barrier fence height of at least 0.6 m was required to prevent some frog species from climbing over the fence.
Some amphibian species were still able to climb over barrier fences.
Moving gully pots 10 cm from the kerb reduced the number of great crested newts falling into the gully pots by 80%.

question_details.query: How do different partial harvesting methods in USA forests compare to clearcutting in their impact on salamander populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across USA forests, shelterwood harvesting compared to clearcutting resulted in salamander abundance that was higher, similar, or initially higher then similar, and a meta-analysis reported that partial harvests including shelterwood caused smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting [851]. Harvesting groups of trees did not yield higher amphibian or salamander abundance than clearcutting in three USA studies, though a meta-analysis found that partial harvests including group selection produced smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting [844]. Thinning showed higher abundance or a less negative overall response than clearcuts in some studies, with other studies showing mixed effects by species and time since harvest; emigrating salamanders used thinned stands significantly more than clearcuts; and a meta-analysis found that partial harvests including thinning produced smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting [852].
summary_statements: Across USA forests, shelterwood harvesting resulted in salamander abundance that was higher, similar, or initially higher then similar when compared to clearcutting.
A meta-analysis reported that partial harvests including shelterwood caused smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
In three USA studies, harvesting groups of trees did not yield higher amphibian or salamander abundance than clearcutting.
A meta-analysis found that partial harvests including group selection produced smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
In some studies, thinning showed higher salamander abundance or a less negative overall response for salamanders than clearcuts.
Other studies showed that the effects of thinning on salamanders were mixed, depending on the species and the time since harvest.
Emigrating salamanders used thinned forest stands significantly more than clearcuts.
A meta-analysis found that partial harvests including thinning produced smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.

question_details.query: What are the potential benefits and harms of controlling fish populations to protect amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Removing fish by catching increased amphibian abundance or vital rates in several U.S. studies, including higher salamander/frog abundance and improved recruitment, survival, and population growth of Cascades Frog; however, it had no significant effect on Great Crested Newt populations in the UK and did not improve Green Toad breeding success in Sweden, with fish remaining or returning within a few years (827). 
- Eliminating fish using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species, abundance, recruitment, and newt populations in studies from Sweden, the UK, and the USA, and a review reported increased breeding success for four amphibian species; however, when rotenone was applied, many frogs died and some newts showed negative effects (828). 
- Excluding fish with barriers increased axolotl weight gain (829). 
- Draining ponds to eliminate fish increased numbers of amphibian species in the USA; pond restoration/creation that sometimes included drying increased numbers of species and breeding populations of Common Spadefoot Toads and Great Crested Newts in Estonia; and pond drying, sometimes alongside other management, increased breeding success of frog or newt species in the UK and USA (826).
summary_statements: Removing fish by catching increased amphibian abundance or vital rates in several U.S. studies.
The removal of fish by catching led to higher salamander and frog abundance, and improved recruitment, survival, and population growth of Cascades Frog.
Removing fish by catching had no significant effect on Great Crested Newt populations in the UK.
The removal of fish by catching did not improve Green Toad breeding success in Sweden.
In some studies, fish remained or returned within a few years of being removed.
Eliminating fish using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species, abundance, recruitment, and newt populations in studies from Sweden, the UK, and the USA.
A review reported increased breeding success for four amphibian species after fish were eliminated using rotenone.
When rotenone was applied to eliminate fish, many frogs died and some newts showed negative effects.
Excluding fish with barriers increased axolotl weight gain.
Draining ponds to eliminate fish increased numbers of amphibian species in the USA.
Pond restoration and creation that sometimes included drying increased numbers of species and breeding populations of Common Spadefoot Toads and Great Crested Newts in Estonia.
Pond drying, sometimes alongside other management, increased breeding success of frog or newt species in the UK and USA.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of engaging the public in amphibian conservation efforts in Europe and the USA?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Citizen-science monitoring in the UK and USA engaged 100–10,506 volunteers and operated in 16–17 USA states; volunteers undertook 412 surveys, surveyed 121–7,872 sites, swabbed almost 6,000 amphibians and submitted thousands of records [760]. Landowner and volunteer habitat management in Estonia, the USA and the UK engaged between eight and 41,000 volunteers, with individual programmes restoring up to 1,023 ponds or over 11,500 km² of habitat; in Estonia, natterjack toad populations increased following volunteer-involved habitat management [777]. Road-crossing patrols in Germany, Italy and the UK moved large numbers of amphibians (from 7,532 to half a million annually), with over 400 patrols in the UK and 71 patrols averaging 90 person-hours and active for up to 10 years; however, despite assistance, 64–70% of toad populations declined over 6–10 years and at 7% of UK sites over 500 toads were still killed on roads [784]. Public-awareness initiatives in Estonia and the UK, alongside other interventions, increased natterjack toad numbers and created 1,023 ponds; in the UK, campaigns trained 1,016 people at 57 events over four years [831].
summary_statements: Citizen-science monitoring in the UK and USA engaged between 100 and 10,506 volunteers.
Citizen-science monitoring programs for amphibians operated in 16 to 17 USA states.
Volunteers in citizen-science monitoring undertook 412 surveys and surveyed between 121 and 7,872 sites.
As part of monitoring efforts, volunteers swabbed almost 6,000 amphibians and submitted thousands of records.
Landowner and volunteer habitat management programs in Estonia, the USA, and the UK engaged between eight and 41,000 volunteers.
Individual habitat management programmes restored up to 1,023 ponds or over 11,500 km² of habitat.
In Estonia, natterjack toad populations increased following volunteer-involved habitat management.
Road-crossing patrols in Germany, Italy, and the UK moved between 7,532 and half a million amphibians annually.
In the UK, there were over 400 road-crossing patrols for amphibians.
A group of 71 road-crossing patrols averaged 90 person-hours of activity and operated for up to 10 years.
Despite assistance from patrols, 64–70% of toad populations declined over a period of 6 to 10 years.
At 7% of UK sites, over 500 toads were still killed on roads.
Public-awareness initiatives in Estonia and the UK, combined with other interventions, increased natterjack toad numbers.
Public-awareness initiatives, alongside other interventions, led to the creation of 1,023 ponds.
In the UK, public awareness campaigns for amphibians trained 1,016 people at 57 events over four years.

question_details.query: What are the overall success rates for establishing new amphibian populations through translocation or the release of captive-bred individuals?
As an alternative to direct antifungal treatment of amphibians, what environmental management actions can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates that: increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis in four of five studies, although one study found that 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs [770]. Adding salt to a pond containing the chytrid fungus was followed by a population of green and golden bell frogs remaining free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months [762]. Drying ponds combined with fungicidal treatment of resident midwife toads reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis in a before-and-after study in Mallorca [766]. The use of zooplankton to remove chytrid zoospores currently has no evidence on effects on amphibian populations [800].
summary_statements: Increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis in four of five studies.
One study found that a temperature of 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs of chytridiomycosis.
After adding salt to a pond containing the chytrid fungus, a population of green and golden bell frogs remained free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months.
Drying ponds combined with fungicidal treatment of resident midwife toads reduced infection levels of chytridiomycosis.
Drying ponds combined with fungicidal treatment of resident midwife toads did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.
There is currently no evidence on the effects on amphibian populations from using zooplankton to remove chytrid zoospores.

question_details.query: When managing understory vegetation in US forests, how does the effectiveness of herbicide use compare to mechanical removal for amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In the USA, a randomized, replicated, controlled study found mechanical understory reduction increased the number of amphibian species present, but did not change overall amphibian abundance [781]. In contrast, three studies (including two randomized, replicated, controlled studies) reported that understory removal using herbicides had no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance [778].
summary_statements: In the USA, a study found that mechanical understory reduction increased the number of amphibian species present.
A study in the USA found that mechanical understory reduction did not change overall amphibian abundance.
Studies reported that understory removal using herbicides had no effect on amphibian abundance.
Some studies reported that understory removal using herbicides had some negative effects on amphibian abundance.

question_details.query: What does the evidence suggest about the effectiveness of legal and regulatory frameworks, such as species protection laws or financial incentive schemes, for amphibian conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three reviews (including one systematic review) in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development (779). Two reviews in the UK reported that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales (779). Three studies (including one replicated study) in Denmark, Sweden and Taiwan found that payments to farmers created amphibian breeding habitat or increased frog/toad populations (818). However, a second study in Taiwan found that payments did not maintain green tree frog habitat (818). One replicated, site-comparison study in the Netherlands found that ditches managed under agri-environment schemes had higher numbers of amphibian species and higher abundance than those managed conventionally (818).
summary_statements: Three reviews in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development.
Two reviews in the UK reported that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales.
Three studies in Denmark, Sweden and Taiwan found that payments to farmers created amphibian breeding habitat.
Three studies in Denmark, Sweden and Taiwan found that payments to farmers increased frog and toad populations.
A study in Taiwan found that payments did not maintain green tree frog habitat.
A study in the Netherlands found that ditches managed under agri-environment schemes had higher numbers of amphibian species than ditches managed conventionally.
A study in the Netherlands found that ditches managed under agri-environment schemes had higher amphibian abundance than ditches managed conventionally.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of livestock grazing on agricultural lands for amphibian habitats and populations?
What treatments are available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis and how effective are they?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents reports multiple treatments: Antifungal drugs (including itraconazole) cured or increased survival in 12/16 studies overall, while four studies found they did not cure but reduced infection or had mixed results; specifically, itraconazole cured in 6/8 studies, with one showing reduced infection and one mixed, though six studies reported some fungicides caused death or adverse effects [882]. Treating wild or pre-release amphibians with fungicide alongside pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis in a before-and-after study on midwife toads in Mallorca [767, 766]. Heat treatment by raising enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads in 4/5 studies, though one study found 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs [770]. Adding salt to a pond with chytrid was followed by a green and golden bell frog population remaining free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months in one study [762]. Probiotic approaches had mixed results: in three of four randomized, replicated, controlled studies, adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin did not reduce infection rate or death, while one study showed prevention of infection and death; adding antifungal bacteria to soil reduced infection in red-backed salamanders in one study; antimicrobial skin peptides did not significantly increase survival in one study; and three studies found antifungal bacteria reduced weight loss in infected amphibians [764].
summary_statements: Antifungal drugs, including itraconazole, cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis in 12 out of 16 studies.
Four studies found that antifungal drugs did not cure amphibians with chytridiomycosis but instead reduced infection or had mixed results.
The specific antifungal drug itraconazole cured amphibians with chytridiomycosis in 6 out of 8 studies.
One study showed that itraconazole reduced chytridiomycosis infection, and another study on the drug reported mixed results.
Six studies reported that some fungicides caused death or adverse effects in amphibians.
Treating wild or pre-release amphibians with fungicide alongside pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis in a study on midwife toads in Mallorca.
Heat treatment by raising enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis in 4 out of 5 studies.
One study found that a heat treatment of 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs of chytridiomycosis.
In one study, a population of green and golden bell frogs remained free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months after salt was added to the pond.
In three of four randomized, replicated, controlled studies, adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin did not reduce the rate of chytridiomycosis infection or death.
One study showed that adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin prevented both chytridiomycosis infection and death.
Adding antifungal bacteria to soil reduced chytridiomycosis infection in red-backed salamanders in one study.
Antimicrobial skin peptides did not significantly increase survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis in one study.
Three studies found that antifungal bacteria reduced weight loss in amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis.

question_details.query: For amphibian conservation in North America, how do the outcomes of creating new wetlands compare to restoring existing wetlands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In North America, site-comparison studies found that restored wetlands generally supported amphibian abundance, species numbers and species composition similar to natural wetlands in 8 of 10 cases, with two studies finding lower or different outcomes; additional USA studies reported that outcomes in restored wetlands were influenced by wetland size, proximity to source ponds and seasonality, but not age [879]. For created wetlands in the USA, five site-comparison studies found similar amphibian species numbers, abundance or communities (depending on depth) to natural wetlands, while two studies found fewer species or lower abundance and different communities; studies in the USA (and Kenya) documented colonization of created wetlands by four to 15 amphibian species [880]. A global review and USA site-comparison studies that evaluated both created and restored wetlands reported amphibian species numbers and abundance were higher or similar to natural wetlands overall (higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35%) [880]. Across multiple regions including the USA, five of nine site-comparison studies reported similar or higher numbers of species or breeding species in created ponds than in natural ponds, though several studies found differences in species composition and one found less stable populations in created ponds; some studies that included the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained or increased amphibian populations or increased species numbers [869].
summary_statements: In North America, site-comparison studies found that restored wetlands generally supported amphibian abundance, species numbers, and species composition similar to natural wetlands in 8 of 10 cases.
Two studies in North America found that restored wetlands had lower or different amphibian outcomes compared to natural wetlands.
Additional USA studies reported that outcomes in restored wetlands were influenced by wetland size, proximity to source ponds, and seasonality.
Additional USA studies reported that outcomes in restored wetlands were not influenced by the age of the wetland.
For created wetlands in the USA, five site-comparison studies found amphibian species numbers, abundance, or communities similar to natural wetlands.
Two studies on created wetlands in the USA found fewer amphibian species, lower abundance, and different communities compared to natural wetlands.
Studies in the USA and Kenya documented the colonization of created wetlands by four to fifteen amphibian species.

A global review and USA site-comparison studies that evaluated both created and restored wetlands reported that overall, amphibian species numbers and abundance were higher than or similar to natural wetlands.
In a global review and USA studies, amphibian species numbers and abundance in created and restored wetlands were higher than in natural wetlands in 54% of studies.
In a global review and USA studies, amphibian species numbers and abundance in created and restored wetlands were similar to natural wetlands in 35% of studies.
Across multiple regions including the USA, five of nine site-comparison studies reported similar or higher numbers of species or breeding species in created ponds than in natural ponds.
Several studies found differences in species composition between created ponds and natural ponds.
One study found less stable amphibian populations in created ponds compared to natural ponds.
Some studies that included the USA found that pond creation maintained or increased amphibian populations or increased species numbers.
In three cases, studies that included the USA found that pond restoration maintained or increased amphibian populations or increased species numbers.

question_details.query: What are the documented impacts of using prescribed fire on amphibian populations in US forest and grassland habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Forests (USA-focused evidence): Two studies in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance either increased or decreased with time since prescribed forest fires (Action 877). One before-and-after study in the USA reported that spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire (Action 877). Broader evidence summarized across Australia, North America and the USA reported varied outcomes: eight of 14 studies found no effect of prescribed forest fires on amphibian abundance or number of species, four found mixed effects depending on species and context, three found increases, and one found decreases (Action 877). Grasslands (USA-focused evidence): Annual prescribed fires in grasslands decreased numbers of amphibian species and abundance in studies from the USA and Argentina, and when combined with grazing regime changes, increased rates of species loss (Action 862). A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that spring burns, but not autumn or winter burns, decreased salamander abundance (Action 862).
summary_statements: Two studies in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance either increased or decreased with time since prescribed forest fires.
One before-and-after study in the USA reported that spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire.
In a summary of 14 studies on prescribed forest fires, eight found no effect on amphibian abundance or number of species.
In a summary of 14 studies on prescribed forest fires, four found mixed effects on amphibians depending on species and context.
In a summary of 14 studies on prescribed forest fires, three found increases in amphibian abundance or number of species.
In a summary of 14 studies on prescribed forest fires, one found decreases in amphibian abundance or number of species.
Annual prescribed fires in grasslands decreased numbers of amphibian species and abundance in studies from the USA and Argentina.
Annual prescribed fires in grasslands, when combined with grazing regime changes, increased rates of amphibian species loss.
A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that spring burns decreased salamander abundance.
A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that autumn or winter burns did not decrease salamander abundance.

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence on the effectiveness of removing various types of invasive predators to benefit native amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence indicates that removing invasive amphibians and other predators can benefit some native amphibians, with mixed results depending on predator type and context. Removing invasive Cuban tree frogs was followed by increases in squirrel tree frog and green tree frog abundance (822). Removing American bullfrogs significantly increased a population of California red‑legged frogs, eradication increased the range of leopard frogs, and red‑legged frogs were observed out in the open twice as frequently after removal (825). Predator control targeting mammals showed no significant effect on Hochstetter’s frog when rats were controlled, but survival of Maud Island frogs was significantly higher in a predator‑proof enclosure, and 58% of translocated Hamilton’s frogs survived their first year in a predator‑proof enclosure (839). Removing fish by catching increased abundance of salamanders or frogs and improved recruitment, survival and population growth rate of cascades frog in multiple studies, but had no significant effect on great crested newts in one UK case and did not increase green toad breeding success in Sweden, with fish persisting or being reintroduced (827). There is currently no direct evidence on the effects of removing or controlling non‑native crayfish on amphibians (797). Intensive removal of viperine snakes increased numbers of Mallorcan midwife toad larvae, whereas less intensive removal did not (830).
summary_statements: Evidence indicates that removing invasive amphibians and other predators can benefit some native amphibians.
The results of removing invasive predators to benefit native amphibians are mixed and depend on the predator type and context.
Removing invasive Cuban tree frogs was followed by increases in squirrel tree frog and green tree frog abundance.
Removing American bullfrogs significantly increased a population of California red‑legged frogs.
The eradication of American bullfrogs increased the range of leopard frogs.
After the removal of American bullfrogs, red-legged frogs were observed out in the open twice as frequently.
Predator control targeting mammals by controlling rats showed no significant effect on Hochstetter’s frog.
The survival of Maud Island frogs was significantly higher in a predator‑proof enclosure.
58% of translocated Hamilton’s frogs survived their first year in a predator‑proof enclosure.
In multiple studies, removing fish by catching increased the abundance of salamanders or frogs.
Removing fish by catching improved recruitment, survival and population growth rate of the cascades frog in multiple studies.
The removal of fish had no significant effect on great crested newts in one UK case.
The removal of fish did not increase green toad breeding success in Sweden, where fish persisted or were reintroduced.
There is currently no direct evidence on the effects of removing or controlling non‑native crayfish on amphibians.
The intensive removal of viperine snakes increased the numbers of Mallorcan midwife toad larvae.
Less intensive removal of viperine snakes did not increase the numbers of Mallorcan midwife toad larvae.

question_details.query: How does the success of reintroduction programs using captive-bred amphibians differ for Mallorcan midwife toads in Mallorca compared to green and golden bell frogs in Australia?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In Mallorca, releases of captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads established breeding populations at a substantial proportion of sites, with studies reporting establishment at 38% of sites when released as tadpoles, 80% when released as toadlets, and 100% when released as adults; a reintroduced captive-bred population maintained predator defences but showed reduced genetic diversity [873]. In Australia, captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released mainly as tadpoles generally failed to establish breeding populations, with only one of four release programmes achieving a stable breeding population; only a small proportion of released tadpoles survived at least 13 months [872].
summary_statements: In Mallorca, releases of captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads established breeding populations at a substantial proportion of sites.
Studies reported establishment of Mallorcan midwife toad breeding populations at 38% of sites when the toads were released as tadpoles.
Studies reported establishment of Mallorcan midwife toad breeding populations at 80% of sites when the toads were released as toadlets.
Studies reported establishment of Mallorcan midwife toad breeding populations at 100% of sites when the toads were released as adults.
A reintroduced captive-bred population of Mallorcan midwife toads maintained predator defences.
A reintroduced captive-bred population of Mallorcan midwife toads showed reduced genetic diversity.
In Australia, captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released mainly as tadpoles generally failed to establish breeding populations.
Only one of four release programmes for green and golden bell frogs in Australia achieved a stable breeding population.
Only a small proportion of released green and golden bell frog tadpoles in Australia survived at least 13 months.

question_details.query: In Australian captive breeding programs, how do artificial fertilization and hormone treatments compare in their success and challenges for frogs?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies that include Australia, artificial fertilization success depended on the type and number of hormonal doses used to stimulate egg production, with one Australian study reporting 55% of eggs fertilized but dying soon afterward (834). Hormone treatments used to induce sperm and egg release showed mixed outcomes: most replicated studies that included Australia found male treatments stimulated or increased sperm production or resulted in successful captive breeding, though one study reported no breeding; sperm amount and viability were affected by hormone type, amount, or dosing regimen (883). For females, studies that included Australia reported variable results, with 30–71% of females producing viable eggs following treatment or outcomes depending on hormone combinations, amounts, or dosing frequency; some studies found no increase in egg production (883). Post-treatment outcomes also varied: some studies reported successful rearing of hormonally induced eggs to tadpoles, toadlets, or froglets, while others reported high mortality before or soon after hatching (883).
summary_statements: The success of artificial fertilization in studies including Australia depended on the type and number of hormonal doses used to stimulate egg production.
One Australian study reported that 55% of frog eggs were fertilized but died soon afterward.
Hormone treatments used to induce sperm and egg release in frogs showed mixed outcomes.
Most replicated studies that included Australia found male hormone treatments stimulated or increased sperm production or resulted in successful captive breeding.
One study reported no breeding in frogs following hormone treatments for males.
The amount and viability of frog sperm were affected by the type, amount, or dosing regimen of hormones.
For female frogs, studies that included Australia reported variable results from hormone treatments.
Following hormone treatment, 30–71% of female frogs produced viable eggs.
The outcomes of hormone treatments for female frogs depended on hormone combinations, amounts, or dosing frequency.
Some studies found no increase in egg production in female frogs following hormone treatments.
Post-treatment outcomes for hormonally induced eggs also varied.
Some studies reported the successful rearing of hormonally induced eggs to tadpoles, toadlets, or froglets.
Other studies reported high mortality for hormonally induced eggs before or soon after hatching.

question_details.query: As an alternative to creating new ponds, what species augmentation techniques can be used to establish or increase amphibian populations at a site?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence-based species augmentation techniques for amphibians include: translocating amphibians (eggs, juveniles or adults), which established breeding populations or substantial recruitment in 35 of 54 assessed cases globally (65%), with higher success reported when >1,000 animals were moved and no clear effect of source, life-stage, continent or reason for translocation [854]; frog translocations that established breeding at 79–100% of sites in most studies, though some efforts failed, with varied survival and notable post-release movements reported [861]; toad translocations that established breeding in some cases and, in one case alongside habitat management, increased population numbers, with reported reproduction and multi-year survival of some translocated adults or metamorphs [855]; salamander/newt translocations that established breeding populations in multiple studies, with reproduction and survival comparable to donor ponds in some cases [860]. Releasing captive-bred amphibians is another approach: one review found 41% of programmes showed breeding in the wild for multiple generations, 29% showed some breeding and 12% showed survival following release [871]; captive-bred frogs released as tadpoles, juveniles or adults established populations or stable breeding populations at 88–100% of sites in several studies (with some failures), and sometimes colonized new sites [870]; captive-bred salamanders/newts released at various life-stages established stable breeding populations in one study [874]. Head-starting (rearing eggs/larvae to later stages before release) has established breeding populations or increased populations in several cases, though results are mixed; many studies report successful metamorphosis, seasonal survival and breeding after release [881]. Captive breeding capacity exists to supply individuals for augmentation, with numerous studies reporting successful egg production and rearing of frogs and salamanders/newts in captivity, though outcomes vary by species and husbandry conditions [835, 838].
summary_statements: Evidence-based species augmentation techniques for amphibians include translocating amphibians like eggs, juveniles, or adults.
Translocating amphibians established breeding populations or substantial recruitment in 65% of assessed cases globally.
The success of amphibian translocation was reported to be higher when more than 1,000 animals were moved.
The success of amphibian translocation was not clearly affected by the source population, the life-stage of the moved animals, the continent, or the reason for the translocation.
Frog translocations established breeding at 79–100% of sites in most studies.
Some frog translocation efforts have failed, with varied survival and notable post-release movements reported.
Toad translocations have established breeding in some cases.
In one case, toad translocation alongside habitat management increased population numbers.
Reproduction and multi-year survival have been reported for some translocated adult toads or metamorphs.
Salamander and newt translocations established breeding populations in multiple studies.
In some cases, the reproduction and survival of translocated salamanders and newts were comparable to those in donor ponds.
Releasing captive-bred amphibians is another approach for species augmentation.
One review found that 41% of captive-bred amphibian release programmes showed breeding in the wild for multiple generations.
The same review found that 29% of programmes showed some breeding and 12% showed survival following release.
Captive-bred frogs released as tadpoles, juveniles, or adults established populations or stable breeding populations at 88–100% of sites in several studies.
Captive-bred frogs released into the wild have sometimes colonized new sites.
Captive-bred salamanders and newts released at various life-stages established stable breeding populations in one study.
Head-starting, which involves rearing eggs or larvae to later stages before release, has established or increased amphibian populations in several cases.
The results of head-starting amphibians are mixed, though many studies report successful metamorphosis, seasonal survival, and breeding after release.
Captive breeding capacity exists to supply individual amphibians for population augmentation.
Numerous studies report successful egg production and rearing of frogs, salamanders, and newts in captivity.
The outcomes of captive breeding amphibians vary by species and husbandry conditions.

question_details.query: To protect migrating amphibians, how do physical interventions like tunnels and barrier fences compare to closing roads during migration seasons?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Evidence on physical interventions shows: Six of seven studies found that installing culverts/tunnels reduced amphibian road deaths (one only when barrier fencing was also installed), while one study found no effect [884]; seven of eight studies found that barrier fencing used with culverts decreased road deaths, though effectiveness depended on fence design and materials [756]. Culverts/tunnels were used by amphibians in 15 of 24 studies (15–85% of individuals or 3–15 species, or 23–100% of structures used), with usage influenced by factors such as diameter, length, lighting, substrate, water presence, and tunnel climate; many sites had barrier fencing guiding animals to entrances [884]. Some species can climb barriers: barriers ≥0.6 m were needed to prevent green and leopard frogs climbing, and treefrogs and 10% of common toads climbed over fences in some studies [756]. 

Evidence on road closures shows: Two studies in Germany reported that large numbers of amphibians were protected from death at road closure sites, including sites with assisted crossings and barrier fences [842]. Patrol-based assistance during migrations moved large numbers of amphibians (thousands to hundreds of thousands), but some monitored populations still declined by 64–70% over 6–10 years, and at 7% of UK sites >500 toads were still killed despite assistance [784].
summary_statements: Six of seven studies found that installing culverts or tunnels reduced amphibian road deaths.
In one study, culverts or tunnels only reduced amphibian road deaths when barrier fencing was also installed.
One study found that installing culverts or tunnels had no effect on amphibian road deaths.
Seven of eight studies found that barrier fencing used with culverts decreased road deaths.
The effectiveness of barrier fencing in decreasing road deaths depended on fence design and materials.
Culverts or tunnels were used by amphibians in 15 of 24 studies.
Amphibian usage of culverts or tunnels was influenced by factors such as diameter, length, lighting, substrate, water presence, and tunnel climate.
Many sites had barrier fencing guiding animals to the entrances of culverts or tunnels.
Some amphibian species can climb barriers.
Barriers of at least 0.6 meters were needed to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing.
Treefrogs climbed over fences in some studies.
In some studies, 10% of common toads climbed over fences.
Two studies in Germany reported that large numbers of amphibians were protected from death at road closure sites.
The road closure sites in two German studies included sites with assisted crossings and barrier fences.
Patrol-based assistance during migrations moved large numbers of amphibians, ranging from thousands to hundreds of thousands.
Some monitored amphibian populations still declined by 64–70% over 6–10 years even with patrol-based assistance.
At 7% of United Kingdom sites, more than 500 toads were still killed despite patrol-based assistance.

question_details.query: What are the typical outcomes when creating new ponds to support toad populations in Europe?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across European studies, creating new ponds has been associated with increases or maintenance of target toad populations, including significant population increases or maintenance at 75% of sites for natterjack toads when combined with other interventions (866). Green toads showed population increases with pond creation alongside other measures in Denmark, and used 59% and reproduced in 41% of created ponds in Sweden (864). For toads more broadly, translocated and naturally colonizing toads established breeding populations in created ponds in Germany and the UK, while common and midwife toads naturally colonized 29–100% of created ponds; however, captive-bred garlic toads did not colonize, and midwife toads reproduced in 16% of created ponds (868). In created ponds for natterjack toads, tadpole mortality from desiccation was lower than in natural ponds, but mortality from invertebrate predation was higher (866).
summary_statements: Across European studies, creating new ponds has been associated with increases or maintenance of target toad populations.
Creating new ponds for natterjack toads, when combined with other interventions, resulted in significant population increases or maintenance at 75% of sites.
In Denmark, green toads showed population increases with pond creation alongside other measures.
Green toads in Sweden used 59% of created ponds.
Green toads in Sweden reproduced in 41% of created ponds.
In Germany and the UK, translocated and naturally colonizing toads established breeding populations in created ponds.
Common and midwife toads naturally colonized 29–100% of created ponds.
Captive-bred garlic toads did not colonize created ponds.
Midwife toads reproduced in 16% of created ponds.
In created ponds for natterjack toads, tadpole mortality from desiccation was lower than in natural ponds.
In created ponds for natterjack toads, mortality from invertebrate predation was higher than in natural ponds.

question_details.query: What are some alternatives to clearcutting forests, and what are their documented effects on amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified alternatives and documented effects on amphibians include: 1) Shelterwood harvesting instead of clearcutting: Across three USA studies, salamander abundance was higher, similar, or initially higher then similar compared to clearcutting; a meta-analysis of 24 North American studies found partial harvest (including shelterwood among other types) caused smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting; compared to no harvesting, two of three studies found shelterwood decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition, while one found no effect; one randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study reported female reproductive metrics (proportion of females with eggs, eggs per female, proportion of juveniles) were similar or lower in harvested plots that included shelterwood, depending on species and time since harvest [851]. 2) Patch retention instead of clearcutting: No evidence was found for effects on amphibian populations; one replicated study in Canada reported released red-legged frogs did not show significant movement towards retained patches, but larger patches were selected more and had fewer movements out than small patches [847].
summary_statements: Shelterwood harvesting is an alternative to clearcutting.
Across three USA studies, salamander abundance in areas with shelterwood harvesting was higher, similar, or initially higher then similar compared to areas with clearcutting.
A meta-analysis of 24 North American studies found that partial harvest, which includes shelterwood harvesting, caused smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
Compared to no harvesting, two of three studies found shelterwood harvesting decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition.
Compared to no harvesting, one of three studies found shelterwood harvesting had no effect on salamanders.
One study reported that female reproductive metrics were similar or lower in harvested plots that included shelterwood.
The effect of shelterwood harvesting on female reproductive metrics depends on the species and the time since the harvest.
Patch retention is an alternative to clearcutting.
No evidence was found for the effects of patch retention on amphibian populations.
One replicated study in Canada reported that released red-legged frogs did not show significant movement towards retained patches of forest.
In a Canadian study, larger retained patches of forest were selected more by red-legged frogs than small patches.
In a Canadian study, larger retained patches of forest had fewer movements of red-legged frogs out of the patches than small patches had.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and potential negative impacts of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads into the wild?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Documented benefits: Captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs established populations in two of three studies, including establishment at 70% of sites in one case [875]. Across head-starting studies, released tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads in six of 10 studies and often metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year, or bred successfully in nine of 10 studies [881]. Head-started individuals showed greater survival to metamorphosis, larger size at metamorphosis, and shorter time to metamorphosis than wild animals in four replicated studies; earlier release increased survival in one study [881].

Documented potential negative impacts: One study found populations were not established from captive-bred and head-started toads [875]. Two studies reported low survival of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads, with 25% predated within two days of release [875]. In head-start programs, two studies found that releases did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population; one study reported adult survival of only 1–17% over four years and another found limited breeding after adult releases; one study found young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than wild conspecifics [881]. Additionally, some studies combined releases with other actions such as translocation or habitat management [881].
summary_statements: Captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs established populations in two of three studies.
In one case, captive-bred toads established populations at 70% of release sites.
Across head-starting studies, released tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads in six of 10 studies.
Released individuals in head-starting studies often metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year, or bred successfully in nine of 10 studies.
Head-started individuals showed greater survival to metamorphosis, larger size at metamorphosis, and shorter time to metamorphosis than wild animals in four replicated studies.
Earlier release of head-started individuals increased survival in one study.
One study found populations were not established from captive-bred and head-started toads.
Two studies reported low survival of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads.
In one instance of low survival, 25% of released Puerto Rican crested toads were predated within two days of release.
In head-start programs, two studies found that releases did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population.
One study reported adult survival of only 1–17% over four years for released individuals.
Another study found limited breeding after adult toad releases.
One study found young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than wild conspecifics.
Some studies combined releases with other actions such as translocation or habitat management.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken to provide or improve shelter and refuge habitats for amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified actions include: creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats, for which no studies were found that quantitatively tested effects on amphibian populations [813]. Creating refuges on land by adding coarse woody debris to forest floors showed no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall abundance but mixed effects on individual species in two replicated, controlled studies; restoration that included reintroducing coarse woody debris increased frog species in one before-and-after study; creating refugia for great crested newts alongside other interventions maintained four populations in one replicated, before-and-after study; artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton’s frogs and hellbenders, though few were used for breeding [772]. Creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites, alongside other terrestrial habitat management, maintained great crested newt populations in one replicated, before-and-after study; created hibernacula were used by common frog and smooth newts but not great crested newts in one replicated study; four amphibian species were found close to hibernacula at two of three sites in one replicated study [759]. Leaving coarse woody debris in forests yielded mixed results: two replicated, controlled studies found no significant differences in abundance for eight of nine species and a more negative overall response where debris was retained; two replicated, controlled studies found removing debris from standing forest did not decrease diversity or overall abundance but did reduce species richness in one study; one replicated, controlled study found migrating amphibians used clearcuts with debris retained more than where it was removed; one replicated, site comparison study found higher survival of juvenile amphibians in piles of woody debris than in open areas and similar survival to unharvested forest [843].
summary_statements: Creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats is an identified action to improve amphibian shelter.
No studies were found that quantitatively tested the effects of creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats on amphibian populations.
Creating refuges on land by adding coarse woody debris to forest floors showed no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall amphibian abundance.
Adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had mixed effects on individual amphibian species.
Restoration that included reintroducing coarse woody debris increased the number of frog species.
Creating refugia for great crested newts alongside other interventions maintained four populations of the newts.
Artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton’s frogs and hellbenders.
Few artificial refugia were used for breeding by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders.
Creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites, alongside other terrestrial habitat management, maintained great crested newt populations.
Created hibernacula were used by common frogs and smooth newts.
Created hibernacula were not used by great crested newts in one study.
Four amphibian species were found close to hibernacula at two of three study sites.
Leaving coarse woody debris in forests yielded mixed results for amphibians.
Retaining coarse woody debris in forests resulted in no significant differences in abundance for eight of nine amphibian species in two studies.
A more negative overall response from amphibians was found where coarse woody debris was retained.
Removing debris from a standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall abundance.
Removing debris from a standing forest did reduce species richness in one study.
Migrating amphibians used clearcuts with retained woody debris more than clearcuts where the debris was removed.
Juvenile amphibians had higher survival rates in piles of woody debris than in open areas.
The survival rate of juvenile amphibians in piles of woody debris was similar to the survival rate in an unharvested forest.

question_details.query: What factors have been found to influence the success of amphibian translocation projects?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study, 65% (35/54) of assessed amphibian translocations established breeding populations or substantial recruitment; two additional translocations resulted in breeding and one in post-release survival (854). One review found that projects releasing over 1,000 animals were more successful (854). The same review reported that success was not related to the source of animals (wild or captive), life-stage, continent, or the reason for translocation (854).
summary_statements: Across three global reviews and one replicated, before-and-after study, 65% of assessed amphibian translocations established breeding populations or substantial recruitment.
Two additional amphibian translocations resulted in breeding.
One additional amphibian translocation resulted in post-release survival.
One review found that amphibian translocation projects releasing over 1,000 animals were more successful.
A review reported that the success of amphibian translocation was not related to the source of animals, whether wild or captive.
A review reported that the success of amphibian translocation was not related to the life-stage of the animals.
A review reported that the success of amphibian translocation was not related to the continent.
A review reported that the success of amphibian translocation was not related to the reason for the translocation.

question_details.query: In the USA, how do partial harvesting techniques like shelterwood, leave-tree, and group harvesting compare in their effects on salamander populations versus clearcutting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies from the USA, shelterwood harvesting compared to clearcutting resulted in salamander abundances that were higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar, depending on study and timing (851). A meta-analysis of 24 North American studies reported that partial harvest approaches (including shelterwood, group or individual tree harvesting, and thinning) produced smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (851, 844). However, harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance than clearcutting in three USA studies (844), and leave-tree harvesting (retaining a low density of trees) likewise did not result in higher salamander abundance than clearcutting in two USA studies (846).
summary_statements: In studies from the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in salamander abundances that were higher than, similar to, or initially higher and then similar to abundances after clearcutting.
A meta-analysis of 24 North American studies reported that partial harvest approaches produced smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
Partial harvest approaches include shelterwood, group or individual tree harvesting, and thinning.
Harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance than clearcutting in three USA studies.
Leave-tree harvesting, which involves retaining a low density of trees, did not result in higher salamander abundance than clearcutting in two USA studies.

question_details.query: What have been the observed effects of excluding livestock from ponds and streams on amphibian populations in the USA and UK?

summary_details.relevant_summary: USA: Across three replicated, site comparison studies, excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species or overall abundance, but it did increase larval abundance and the abundance of green frog metamorphs; two studies found the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher under grazing (746). A randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study found excluding cattle from ponds did not increase numbers of eggs or larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs (746). A replicated, randomized, controlled study in wet grasslands found no difference in Yosemite toad abundance between cattle-excluded and grazed areas (2319). UK: A before-and-after study reported that pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads (746).
summary_statements: In the USA, excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the number of amphibian species.
In the USA, excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase the overall abundance of amphibians.
Excluding livestock from streams or ponds in the USA did increase amphibian larval abundance.
Excluding livestock from streams or ponds in the USA did increase the abundance of green frog metamorphs.
In the USA, two studies found the abundance of green frogs and American toads was higher under grazing.
Excluding cattle from ponds in the USA did not increase the numbers of eggs of Columbia spotted frogs.
Excluding cattle from ponds in the USA did not increase the larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs.
In the USA, a study in wet grasslands found no difference in Yosemite toad abundance between cattle-excluded and grazed areas.
In the UK, pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads.

question_details.query: What design and placement factors are associated with the successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Tunnel dimensions and geometry: Wider-diameter culverts/tunnels were used more in three of six studies, and longer tunnels were avoided in one of two studies [884].
- Lighting: Tunnel lighting affected use in all three studies that tested it, with mixed effects reported [884].
- Substrate: Natural substrates inside tunnels were used more in three of six studies [884].
- Water presence: The presence of water had mixed effects in two of three studies; culverts with flowing water were used by amphibians in multiple studies and were used more or the same amount as dry culverts in some cases [884].
- Entrance location and tunnel climate: Entrance location affected use in one study, and tunnel climate affected use in one study [884].
- Guidance and fencing: The majority of tunnels studied had barrier fencing to guide amphibians to entrances [884]; installing culverts/tunnels decreased amphibian road deaths in most studies, including cases where reductions occurred only when barrier fencing was also installed [884]. Barrier fencing with culverts decreased road deaths when fence length and material were effective [756]. Barriers at least 0.6 m high were required to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing over, though treefrogs and around 10% of common toads were recorded climbing over barriers during breeding migrations [756].
- Design cautions: One-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes led to high mortality of common toads, and condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations [884].
summary_statements: Wider-diameter culverts and tunnels were used more by migrating amphibians in some studies.
Longer tunnels were avoided by migrating amphibians in one study.
Tunnel lighting affected the use of tunnels by migrating amphibians in all studies that tested the feature.
The effects of tunnel lighting on use by migrating amphibians were mixed.
Tunnels with natural substrates inside were used more by migrating amphibians in some studies.
The presence of water in tunnels had mixed effects on amphibian usage.
Culverts with flowing water were used by amphibians in multiple studies.
Culverts with flowing water were used more or the same amount as dry culverts in some cases.
The location of the tunnel entrance affected amphibian use in one study.
The climate inside the tunnel affected amphibian use in one study.
The majority of tunnels studied had barrier fencing to guide amphibians to the entrances.
Installing culverts or tunnels decreased amphibian road deaths in most studies.
In some cases, reductions in amphibian road deaths occurred only when barrier fencing was also installed.
Barrier fencing used with culverts decreased road deaths when the fence length and material were effective.
Barriers at least 0.6 meters high were required to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing over the barriers.
Treefrogs and around 10% of common toads were recorded climbing over barriers during breeding migrations.
One-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes led to high mortality of common toads.
Condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations.

question_details.query: In US forests, how do mechanical and herbicide-based methods for controlling understory vegetation compare in their effects on amphibians?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies in the USA, herbicide-based understory removal showed no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance (ID: 778). In contrast, a randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found mechanical understory reduction increased the number of amphibian species while not changing overall abundance (ID: 781).
summary_statements: Across studies in the USA, herbicide-based understory removal showed no effect on amphibian abundance.
Across studies in the USA, herbicide-based understory removal showed some negative effects on amphibian abundance.
A randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found mechanical understory reduction increased the number of amphibian species.
A randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found mechanical understory reduction did not change overall amphibian abundance.

question_details.query: What legal and regulatory actions are available to protect wild amphibian populations from threats like development and trade?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Legislative regulation to reduce trade has been associated with recovery of over-exploited frog populations [785, 824]. Legal protection of amphibian species during development was reported as not effective at protecting populations in reviews from the Netherlands and UK [779]. The number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued in England and Wales increased over a 10‑year period to over 600 under the legal protection framework [779]. In South Africa, the number of permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990 under permitting systems [785]. For commercially breeding amphibians for the pet trade as a regulatory or management response, there is currently no evidence on effects on wild populations [794].
summary_statements: Legislative regulation to reduce trade has been associated with recovery of over-exploited frog populations.
Legal protection of amphibian species during development was reported as not effective at protecting populations in reviews from the Netherlands and UK.
The number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued in England and Wales increased to over 600 over a 10‑year period under the legal protection framework.
In South Africa, the number of permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990 under permitting systems.
There is currently no evidence on the effects on wild populations from commercially breeding amphibians for the pet trade as a regulatory or management response.

question_details.query: For natterjack toad conservation in the UK, what are the documented benefits and negative side effects of adding lime to ponds?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Documented UK benefits of adding limestone to ponds for natterjack toad conservation include: establishment of one of three translocated natterjack populations (748); increased natterjack populations when lime addition was part of species-specific habitat management (748); and temporary increases in natterjack breeding (748). Documented UK negative side effects include: high natterjack tadpole mortality and subsequent pond abandonment (748); and increased numbers of abnormal common frog eggs (748).
summary_statements: In the UK, adding limestone to ponds for natterjack toad conservation has contributed to the establishment of one of three translocated natterjack populations.
Adding lime as part of species-specific habitat management in the UK has increased natterjack toad populations.
A documented benefit of adding limestone to ponds for natterjack toad conservation in the UK includes temporary increases in natterjack breeding.
A documented negative side effect of adding lime to UK ponds is high natterjack tadpole mortality and subsequent pond abandonment.
Adding lime to UK ponds has been documented to cause increased numbers of abnormal common frog eggs.

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence on creating or restoring terrestrial habitat connectivity, such as through hedgerows, for amphibian populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in Australia found that retaining native vegetation corridors maintained populations of eight of 13 frog species over 20 years [853]. One before-and-after study in Italy found that restoring connectivity between two wetlands by raising a road on a viaduct significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians [840]. There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects of creating habitat connectivity on amphibian populations [811]. There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects of maintaining or restoring hedges on amphibian populations [790]. There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects of planting hedges on amphibian populations [791].
summary_statements: A before-and-after study in Australia found that retaining native vegetation corridors maintained populations of eight of 13 frog species over 20 years.
A before-and-after study in Italy found that restoring connectivity between two wetlands by raising a road on a viaduct significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects of creating habitat connectivity on amphibian populations.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects of maintaining or restoring hedges on amphibian populations.
There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects of planting hedges on amphibian populations.

question_details.query: To manage chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians, what are the most and least beneficial treatment strategies?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis in four of five studies; one study found that 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs [770].
- Antifungal treatments cured or increased survival in 12 of 16 studies; four studies reported reduced infection levels or mixed results. Itraconazole was effective at curing in six of eight studies; one study reported reduced infection levels and one mixed effects. Six studies found specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects [882].
- Adding antifungal skin bacteria did not reduce infection rate or death in three of four randomized, replicated, controlled studies; one study found prevention of infection and death. Adding antifungal bacteria to soil reduced infection rate in red-backed salamanders in one study. Treatment with antimicrobial skin peptides before or after infection did not significantly increase survival in one study. Three studies found adding antifungal skin bacteria reduced weight loss in infected amphibians [764].
- Treating wild midwife toads with fungicide, along with pond drying, reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis in a before-and-after study; this involved treatment in the wild or pre-release contexts [767].
- Addition of salt to a pond where the chytrid fungus was present was followed by a population of green and golden bell frogs remaining free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months in one study [762].
summary_statements: Increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis in four of five studies.
One study found that a temperature of 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs of chytridiomycosis.
Antifungal treatments cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis in 12 of 16 studies.
Four studies on antifungal treatments for chytridiomycosis reported reduced infection levels or mixed results.
The antifungal Itraconazole was effective at curing chytridiomycosis in six of eight studies.
One study on Itraconazole reported reduced infection levels, and one study reported mixed effects.
Six studies found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians.
In three of four randomized, replicated, controlled studies, adding antifungal skin bacteria did not reduce the infection rate or death from chytridiomycosis.
One study found that adding antifungal skin bacteria prevented chytridiomycosis infection and death.
Adding antifungal bacteria to soil reduced the chytridiomycosis infection rate in red-backed salamanders in one study.
In one study, treatment with antimicrobial skin peptides before or after infection did not significantly increase amphibian survival.
Three studies found that adding antifungal skin bacteria reduced weight loss in amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis.
Treating wild midwife toads with fungicide, along with pond drying, reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis in a before-and-after study.

The addition of salt to a pond where the chytrid fungus was present was followed by a population of green and golden bell frogs remaining free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months in one study.

question_details.query: What are the general outcomes of releasing captive-bred toads, including species like the Mallorcan midwife toad?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies of released captive-bred toads, outcomes ranged from successful establishment to low survival and high predation: For Mallorcan midwife toads, captive-bred releases established breeding populations in 38%, 80%, or 100% of sites when released as tadpoles, toadlets, or adults, respectively, and one randomized, replicated, controlled study reported maintained predator defences but reduced genetic diversity in a reintroduced population [873]. For other toads, two of three studies reported establishment of populations from releases of tadpoles, juveniles, or metamorphs (in one case at 70% of sites), while another study reported no establishment from captive-bred and head-started toads; additionally, two studies noted low survival of released Puerto Rican crested toads, with 25% predated within two days of release [875].
summary_statements: Across studies of released captive-bred toads, outcomes ranged from successful establishment to low survival and high predation.
Captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads released as tadpoles established breeding populations in 38% of sites.
Captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads released as toadlets established breeding populations in 80% of sites.
Captive-bred Mallorcan midwife toads released as adults established breeding populations in 100% of sites.
A reintroduced population of Mallorcan midwife toads maintained predator defences.
A reintroduced population of Mallorcan midwife toads experienced reduced genetic diversity.
Two of three studies on other toads reported the establishment of populations from releases of tadpoles, juveniles, or metamorphs.
In one case, populations of other toads were established at 70% of release sites.
Another study reported no establishment from releases of captive-bred and head-started toads.
Low survival was noted for released Puerto Rican crested toads.
25% of released Puerto Rican crested toads were predated within two days of release.

question_details.query: For road mitigation projects, what design factors are associated with the success or failure of tunnels and culverts for amphibian passage?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from studies on amphibian road crossings reports that culvert/tunnel use and mortality outcomes are associated with multiple design and contextual factors: wider culverts were used more often (diameter effect), longer culverts were avoided, lighting had mixed effects, natural substrates were used more than artificial substrates, the presence of water had mixed effects, entrance location affected use in one study, and tunnel climate affected use in one study [884]. One study found culverts/tunnels decreased road deaths only when barrier fencing was also installed, and most culverts/tunnels assessed had barrier fencing to guide amphibians to entrances [884]. Certain designs were unsuitable: one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality of common toads, and condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations [884]. Barrier fencing design influenced effectiveness: decreased deaths depended on fence length and material being effective; barriers at least 0.6 m high were required to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs climbing over; some species (treefrogs and 10% of common toads) climbed over fencing during breeding migrations [756]. Reported use rates varied widely (e.g., 15–85% of individuals, 3–15 species; some studies reported <10% use or no use), and in one case thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road [884].
summary_statements: Culvert and tunnel use and mortality outcomes for amphibians are associated with multiple design and contextual factors.
Wider culverts were used more often by amphibians.
Longer culverts were avoided by amphibians.
Lighting had mixed effects on amphibian use of culverts and tunnels.
Natural substrates were used more than artificial substrates by amphibians in culverts and tunnels.
The presence of water in tunnels and culverts had mixed effects on amphibian use.
One study found that the location of a tunnel's entrance affected its use by amphibians.
One study found that the climate inside a tunnel affected its use by amphibians.
One study found that culverts and tunnels decreased road deaths only when barrier fencing was also installed.
Most culverts and tunnels assessed had barrier fencing to guide amphibians to entrances.
Certain designs for amphibian passage were found to be unsuitable.
One-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality of common toads.
Condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations.
The design of barrier fencing influenced its effectiveness for protecting amphibians.
A decrease in amphibian deaths depended on fence length and the effectiveness of the material used.
Barriers at least 0.6 meters high were required to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing over.
Some species, such as treefrogs and 10% of common toads, climbed over fencing during breeding migrations.
Reported use rates of tunnels and culverts by amphibians varied widely.
In one case, thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road despite mitigation efforts.
